value.title: DAX Fridays! #183: How to deal with multiple dates in Power BI
value.excerpt: So you have order date, shipped date, required date....and only one calendar. How do you manage that in power bi and DAX?  This scenario is often called role playing dimensions and in this video I will show you two ways to solve it. :) Happy Friday!!  Links to videos mentioned: Introduction to data modeling:

value.title: Dax Fridays #211: Add leading zeros to a column using DAX
value.excerpt: Adding leading zeros, is probably something that you should do alrealy in Power Query, but in this case I wanted that column to be created on the fly rather than adding it to the model, so I let me show you how I did it! value.title: DAX Fridays! #42: SUBSTITUTE (multiple values)
value.excerpt: In today's video, we will learn how to use the DAX function SUBSTITUTE.  Substitute changes text for another text. We will do two examples, how to substitute one value for another and how to substitute multiple values. value.title: DAX Fridays! #66: TREATAS
value.excerpt: In this video we will go through the DAX function TREATAS.  The TREATAS DAX function allows us to create virtual relationships within tables or pass filters to tables that are not related.  Link to function in glossary:  https://curbal.com/blog/glossary/treatas-dax   Link to SQLBI blog post: https://www.sqlbi.com/articles/propagate-filters-using-treatas-in-dax/

value.title: DAX Fridays! #74: PREVIOUSDAY, PREVIOUSMONTH, PREVIOUSQUARTER, PREVIOUSYEAR
value.excerpt: In todayâ€™s video I we will go through how to build a time intelligence measure in DAX using the PREVIOUSDAY, PREVIOUSMONTH, PREVIOUSQUARTER, PREVIOUSYEAR.  We will first go through PREVIOUSYEAR DAX function and explain how can those functions can be combined with CALCULATE to create the correct measure.

value.title: DAX Fridays! #: 75: SAMEPERIODLASTYEAR
value.excerpt: In today's video we will go through the DAX function called SAMEPERIODLASTYEAR.  This little function is great for analyzing as the function itself says, the same period last year.  If you have seasonal business and you want to analyze what happended the same period the previous year, it will do it flowless.

value.title: DAX Fridays! #80: DATESBETWEEN
value.excerpt: In todays video we are going to cover the DAX function DATESBETWEEN.  DATESBETWEEN function allows you to calculate amounts between two dates you specify.   For example, if you want to calculate the sum of sales between two specific dates, this is the perfect function for you.  You can "hardcode" the

value.title: Get football data for the main championships for free in Power BI
